results.title: Australia faces double-whammy as coronavirus impact spreads
results.body:
Australia's three-decade unbroken run of economic growth is in large part due to its success in tapping the rise of its largest trading partner, China.

But as the deadly coronavirus outbreak shuts down a swath of the Chinese economy, just as Australia suffers its own crisis in the form of the devastating wildfires emergency, economists are warning that the 28-year stretch is under threat.

"There is a very real risk that gross domestic product will contract as a result of the combined drag from the bushfires and coronavirus," said Sarah Hunter, economist at BIS Oxford Economics. "Whether we go from this to a recession critically depends on how the outbreak unfolds."

Australia's economy was already showing signs of weakness before the wildfires took hold in the fourth quarter. Gross domestic product growth of 1.7 per cent in the year to September compared with 2.8 in the previous 12 months, thanks to weak consumer spending and the pre-virus slowdown in China.

Goldman Sachs has forecast that the fires which burnt millions of acres of land could knock 0.3 percentage points from Australia's GDP growth in the half-year to March. With two-way trade between Australia and China worth A$215bn in 2018, the most-recent data available, the crisis caused by the virus adds to the downside risk.

More than 900 Chinese people have died from the flu-like disease since the outbreak began in the city of Wuhan late last year. It has since spread to more than 20 countries, sparking international alarm and threatening to wreak havoc on the global supply chain.

Illustrating the strains, Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 is down 5 per cent this year and the Australian dollar remains close to near-decade lows of US$0.67 hit late last week.

The Reserve Bank of Australia last week kept interest rates on hold and warned people not to "catastrophise" the virus's impact. But many investors believe the central bank will have to move soon to cut rates from the current record low of 0.75 per cent.

Economists also took aim at the central bank's 2.75 per cent annual growth forecast as too optimistic, given that a figure of 1.7 per cent was reported in December before the virus took hold.

Since then, Canberra's decision to bar entry to foreign nationals who had recently visited China has hit the education sector, which contributes A$37bn to the economy annually.

Half the roughly 200,000 Chinese students due to begin studies this month remain stranded at home, according to the International Education Association of Australia, which estimated a hit of up to A$8bn if they cannot attend the new term. A quarter of University of Sydney's income comes from Chinese students.

There are also concerns of long-lasting reputational damage. "There is a risk international student numbers will drop and not recover after this crisis," said Liam Donohoe, president of the University of Sydney Student Representative Council.

Other China-reliant sectors are also grappling with a sharp fall in demand due to the muted lunar new year celebrations.

Indian Ocean Rock Lobster, an Australian seafood exporter, usually ships five to 10 tonnes of lobster to China each day. But owner Michael Thompson said the "wheels started to fall off" late last month as Chinese families cancelled often-lavish new year banquets and food markets were closed over safety fears. "It's having a domino-effect on everything to do with China. Tourism, lobster . . . prime lamb," he said.

For the tourism industry, the Chinese travel ban has exacerbated a decline prompted by the wildfires. China is Australia's largest tourism market, accounting for 1.5m short-term arrivals in the year to June -- 15 per cent of the total.

Tourism bodies have estimated that cancellations due to the fires could cost up to A$4.5bn. Retail sales were down 0.5 per cent in December at the height of the wildfire emergency that is also expected to have reduced spending in the weeks that followed.

Another worry is whether the slowdown in China caused by the virus will curb demand for natural resources and lower prices of commodities such as iron ore and coal that are vital to Australia's economy. Canberra had forecast that natural resources would generate a record A$281bn in export revenues in 2019-2020 but that is under threat.

If Chinese gas importers follow through on their threat to cancel up to 70 per cent of seaborne imports this month it would also throw that market into turmoil.

Australia's government coffers are also feeling the effect of the economic malaise. The treasury warned this month that the uncertainty could undermine the government's promise to return the budget to surplus in 2020 for the first time in a decade.

While it remains difficult to quantify the lasting impact of the virus, economists believe it will be larger than that of the Sars virus 17 years ago, which cut Australian GDP by only 0.1-0.2 percentage points.

"China is much more important now . . . than it was in 2003," said Saul Eslake, an economist and fellow at University of Tasmania.

Shane Oliver, chief economist at AMP Capital, said there was a high risk that GDP growth in the first three months would be negative due to the double-whammy of the fires and the virus, which he forecast could reduce GDP by 0.5 percentage points in the quarter.

But Mr Eslake said the chance of two consecutive quarters of negative growth that would drag Australia into a technical recession was "relatively small".

"I would say the 28-year run of growth without consecutive quarters of negative growth is likely to remain intact," he said.

results.title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
results.body:
FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

First FT Asia is off tomorrow. We'll be back in your inbox on Wednesday morning.

President Xi Jinping issued orders to contain the deadly coronavirus outbreak almost two weeks earlier than previously thought, according to an account that appears to contradict the narrative that local officials were to blame for allowing the epidemic to spiral.

The official Communist party magazine Qiushi's account over the weekend says that Mr Xi met the party's politburo standing committee, China's most powerful decision-making body, and gave instructions on the virus response on January 7 -- 13 days before the public was warned about the outbreak's severity.

Previous state media accounts appeared to date Mr Xi's earliest direct involvement to a January 20 statement. The magazine instead said he was aware and in charge of the response to the virus almost two weeks earlier, potentially implicating Mr Xi in the bungled early response to the outbreak that contributed to its rapid spread.

Meanwhile, horror stories are emerging from Wuhan as the city struggles to cope with the health crisis. One of the most haunting images to come out of the Chinese city at the centre of the coronavirus outbreak is of a distressed woman in an upper floor apartment banging a homemade gong and wailing for help. (FT)

Further reading:

SoftBank investment chief pushes hedge fund The head of SoftBank's $100bn Vision Fund has lined up billions of dollars of outside investment for a new hedge fund-style vehicle, in a move that threatens to escalate tensions at the world's biggest tech investor. (FT)

US vents about China's 5G at Munich security conference Nancy Pelosi (below), House of Representatives speaker, issued a rebuke to European countries using China's Huawei to build 5G mobile communications networks. Her remarks came after Mark Esper, defence secretary, and Mike Pompeo, secretary of state, also spoke out on the issue. The "west is winning", Mr Pompeo said, but the west wasn't buying it. (FT, New York Times)

UK Budget may be delayed Grant Shapps, transport secretary, said on Sunday that the budget may be delayed following Sajid Javid's resignation as chancellor. Downing Street would not confirm on Friday whether the scheduled March 11 date would be changed or whether the UK's fiscal rules would remain in place. (FT)

China offers to build HS2 in five years and for less money Officials at the UK's Department for Transport said "preliminary discussions" were under way between HS2 Ltd, which is responsible for building the high-speed line, and state-owned China Railway Construction Corporation, but that no commitments had been made. (FT)

Libya ceasefire 'holding by a thread' Stephanie Williams, the deputy UN envoy, described the arms embargo on Libya as a "joke", in a gloomy assessment of the prospects for peace. Fayez al-Sarraj, the head of Libya's internationally recognised government, also warned that his country will face a financial crisis because of the oil blockade by opposition groups. (FT, Al Jazeera)

Israel thwarts Hamas hackers' malware The Israeli military said that it had thwarted a honeytrap scheme by Palestinian militant group Hamas that attempted to hack soldiers' mobile phones by posing as attractive young women. (FT)

US and Taliban agree to truce The two groups have agreed to a temporary truce that, if successful, could pave the way for American troops to leave Afghanistan after 18 years. The deal is a major milestone in America's longest running war, but the possibility of lasting peace remains unclear. (AP)

Vodafone's India venture on brink of collapse India's Supreme Court rejected an application from telecoms companies to defer paying billions of dollars in historic levies to the government, in a ruling that leaves Vodafone's local joint venture on the verge of collapse. (FT)

The world of luxury has changed completely in recent years. How to Spend It, the FT's luxury magazine, is following suit, relaunching this weekend under editor Jo Ellison to start a new dialogue about how we define "spend".

Read an exclusive interview with designer Anya Hindmarch on her new eco-campaign and savour this fashion shoot of 1990s minimalism. Look out for the print edition, with features on the longevity of the Chanel jacket and the renaissance of Christian Lacroix, plus much more.

Japan growth figures Monday's report is expected to show the economy to have contracted. Last month, Japan announced plans to revamp its economic data releases to avoid significant revisions. (FT, Nikkei Asian Review)

Zuckerberg-EU meeting Facebook chief executive and founder Mark Zuckerberg on Monday will discuss regulation with Margrethe Vestager, EU antitrust and digital commissioner, and Thierry Breton. Mr Zuckerberg wrote in the FT that Big Tech needs more regulation. (FT)

Keep up with the important business, economic and political stories in the coming days with the FT's Week Ahead. Click to subscribe here. And don't miss our FT News Briefing audio show -- a short daily rundown of the top global stories.

How digital tools can bolster democracy Big Tech's power to squash competition and degrade liberal democracy is one of the most well-rehearsed storylines of our time. But there is a counter-example -- the power of decentralised technology to support individuals and liberal democracies all over the world, even as surveillance states threaten it. Rana Foroohar found one such example at work in Taiwan. (FT)

For more from Rana, sign up for our Swamp Notes newsletter, where she and Edward Luce discuss money and power in Trump's America.

Inside Syria's final battle There are some 3m civilians trapped in north-west Syria close to the Turkish border, where an intense bombing campaign and advancing ground assault by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad have forced people to consider fleeing. Streets are jammed with loaded cars, families desperate to escape the bombing but with little option of where to go. (FT)

Rising seas from Manila to San Francisco On both sides of the Pacific Ocean, what the fight against sea level rise looks like has a lot to do with whether you were born rich or poor. While investors and customers pressure big companies to reduce their impact, having a climate strategy has also become key for retaining employees. (NYT, Wall Street Journal)

What to watch this week The Battle for Hong Kong is a powerful new documentary that follows five young activists and their fight for democracy. This portrait of Momo, Li, Lomi, Vincent and Agnes Chow (not all their real names) taking to the streets is bound to leave you heartsick. (FT)

Why populist nostalgia will pass For Olga Tokarczuk, the fame that came with winning the Nobel Prize for Literature has been a bit jarring. Even on a recent trip to a hardware store, Tokarczuk was mobbed. "It was also really nice, of course, but after a bit I got scared," the Polish writer said. Over Lunch with the FT, Tokarczuk sounded off on confronting history and her battles with the nationalist right. (FT)

Bosses need to speak out on Instagram and beyond Yes, social media can be risky -- but authenticity is rewarded, and we should hear more of interest from influential executives on platforms like Instagram, not less. Meanwhile, amid the deluge of selfies, Instagram "content creators" are bringing financial education into the social media mainstream. (FT)

'Lift line apocalypse' Photographs and videos of what skiers in Vail dubbed the "lift line apocalypse" went viral on social media last week. A local television station reported some skiers had waited in line for 75 minutes. Meanwhile, a French ski resort angered ecologists by using a helicopter to move snow after a mild winter threatened its ability to stay open. (FT, Guardian)

US accuses Huawei of organised crime Huawei faces a new challenge in the US -- could its executives end up going to jail? The FT's Washington correspondent Kiran Stacey reports.

results.title: Coronavirus sparks feverish trading in search of treatment
results.body:
Investors are bidding up companies trying to alleviate the coronavirus outbreak, from biotechs working on treatments and vaccines to telemedicine companies catering for the sick stuck at home.

Some are seeking "fast money" trades, diving into smaller biotechs with long shots at a vaccine, while others are hunting for more solid long-term investments that could also be buoyed by the epidemic.

"There has been an incredible amount of interest in the biotech industry in the wake of the coronavirus," said Thomas Hayes, chairman of Great Hill Capital, the New York-based hedge fund.

"The market is pouncing on the most likely beneficiaries even though the process of developing a vaccine doesn't happen overnight."

The coronavirus has spread to more people than the 2003 Sars epidemic and has killed more than 800 people. The US is at least the fifth country, including China, in which the infection is spreading through human-to-human contact.

On Friday, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced the temporary suspension of trading in the securities of Aethlon Medical because of concerns that third parties were spreading false information about its product's potential use in the coronavirus outbreak. Aethlon did not respond to a request for comment.

"You will have winners in this race to the finish line on a vaccine or cure, but you will also have investors betting that certain companies have an edge on how to treat the coronavirus -- which may or may not work," Mr Hayes said.

Shares in Gilead Sciences jumped 5 per cent to $66.36 on Monday after the Bay Area-based biotech said it was working with global health authorities on a clinical trial to see whether Remdesivir, a potential drug that is not yet approved by any regulator, could be used to treat the coronavirus.

The company said the drug candidate had been used against the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) and Sars, which are similar coronaviruses, in animal studies. Gilead shares climbed throughout the week and closed on Friday at nearly $69 a share.

Regeneron Pharmaceutical is also working on antibody treatments for the coronavirus, collaborating with the US department of health and human services. The New York-based biotech company said on Thursday that it was hoping to have a drug for testing in some patients within a few months. Shares in Regeneron rose 13 per cent last week.

But there have also been share spikes in smaller biotech companies that have started work on vaccines for the virus despite slim chance of success. Even if their vaccines work, it will take months to conduct human trials and the outbreak may have ended by then.

Shares in Vaxart soared 28 per cent to $1.60 on Monday, after it said it would use its oral vaccine platform to try to develop a tablet vaccine. At the start of the year, Vaxart shares were trading around 36 cents a share.

Vaxart follows several speculative-linked trades in other biotech companies in recent weeks.

Both Inovio Pharmaceuticals and Moderna received funding from the Coalition for Economic Preparedness Innovations, a group of government and charities, to try to create coronavirus vaccines.

Inovio climbed 61 per cent from the start of the year until a peak on January 27 of $5.32, only to fall back to a closing price of $3.19 on Friday. Moderna gained 16 per cent to a peak of $22.74 on January 27, but gave back some of the gains on Monday before finishing at $23.24 on Friday.

Another biotech, Novavax, rose 146 per cent in a week, based on studies showing that its Sars and Mers vaccines worked in animals, before losing more than 10 per cent to close at $6.81 on Monday and $6.31 on Friday.

Brad Loncar, an investor who manages a family fund with a biotech focus, pointed to the last major outbreak -- of Ebola -- and NewLink Genetics, which finally won approval for its Ebola vaccine at the end of last year. Even after approval, NewLink Genetics is trading far below its peak of $55.38 in 2015, at $1.66 on Friday.

"Even if a company successfully develops a vaccine, which will likely take years, there typically isn't a lot of money in it," Mr Loncar said. "While it's possible that a large company like Gilead or AbbVie will be able to use an existing medicine against this as a therapeutic treatment, it's unlikely to be much of a needle mover from a stock market perspective for a large company like that," he added.

Nina Deka, a healthcare analyst at ROBO Global research, said that telemedicine companies were also likely to benefit from the outbreak -- and future pandemics -- as people opted to receive medical help without leaving the house.

Shares in PingAn Good Doctor, the Chinese remote healthcare provider listed in Hong Kong, have gained 27 per cent so far this year, while in the US, Teladoc health has also soared 27 per cent since the start of January.
